Comments_List: In Game Theory I learned how to think strategically about interactions between two parties, especially when certain outside factors (incomplete information) had to be considered. The class helped explain many of the shortcomings of previous studies in economics, and how to analyze negotiations in the real world.

I learned the basics of game theory. More specifically, through the study of simultaneous games, sequential games, repeated games, games of incomplete information, and games of imperfect information, I learned about Nash equilibrium, subgame perfect Nash equilibrium, Bayesian equilibirum, and perfect Bayensian equilibrium.

This is truly one of the worst courses I have ever taken in my now eight semesters at Yale. I wish there had been a textbook to learn from, as that would have been much more conducive to learning than going to lecture. While I appreciate Marina's obvious enthusiasm, passion, and knowledge of game theory, execution of this course was just not effective. The problem sets were generally long and tedious and had no real pedagogical value aside from rehashing the material from lecture, often in unhelpful and convoluted ways that focused more on algebraic or statistical creativity than anything else. The midterm was horrendous. The questions were poorly written and unclear. The grading was both sloppy and unforgiving. The final was no better. I have not up to this point gotten a letter grade below an A- in my 40 credits and eight semesters at Yale; this may be my first C, and not for lack of effort or preparation. In the middle of the semester after spring break, Marina informed the class that some students had been emailing her about the course curve and admitted that she had not been cognizant of the standard economics department curve but promised that she would announce how the curve would be soon before the final. Even after follow-up email inquiry, she never clarified her decision on the course curve. Perhaps worst of all was the extremely inefficient use of classtime in lecture. Marina would often spend up to 40 minutes per class answering student questions at every step of the lecture to the point that she did not have time to adequately cover some of the more difficult concepts (usually saved for the end of the lectures). While I appreciate her willingness to answer each and every question, it was extremely inefficient. Many of the questions were relatively simple, asking for clarification on some minor detail or another, but she ended up overexplaining everything in an extremely repetitive and unhelpful way such that she lost the attention of many students waiting for her to just move on to the next slide. Lectures quickly became exercises in the time-honored virtue of patience. While some may be put off by the overall negative tone of my evaluation, I do so in order to make clear the merits and demerits of this course to rational consumers who seek to make informed decisions about their course selections. Overall, this disaster of a course reflects a deep misunderstanding of basic pedagogy and time management.

Knowledge about game theory and the different kinds of games and how they could be played.

Learned a lot about logical approaches to decisions, how to model decisions with multiple players, etc.
I loved the rigorous nature of the course and the clean and clear structure. However, I wish the homework/midterm grades were a little more descriptive.
The class seemed very well taught but fairly standard. The material was very interesting, but there were not a huge amount of "aha" moments. Overall an excellent class.
Sometimes the way to solve problem sets was a little unclear. Help hours were often on unhelpful days.

Strengths: taught by a pretty great professor, very interesting in the context of real-life applications, highly structured, and workload manageable

The course is taught extremely well! The material is not very hard, which is very encouraging for people who want to understand the concepts without having to rigorously prove them mathematically. However, personally, I probably would have enjoyed a more rigorous class. However, there is already a class that is more rigorous (Mathematical Game Theory), so I would not say that the improvement has to deal with this course.

Professor Halac is a wonderful teacher. She is clear, precise and patient with her explanations and makes it evident that she is invested in her students walking away with a strong grasp on the material and an excitement to learn. While this made the course in many ways worthwhile, the structure and nature of the exams was in many ways counterproductive to allowing all students the chance to grow and demonstrate competency with the material. The midterm was far more accessible than most Econ exams, but this made mistakes incredibly costly. With the problem sets graded on a check/check plus basis, it was nearly impossible after a mediocre midterm performance to even have a chance at getting an A range grade regardless of how well you did on the final. I hope Professor Halac accounts for this in her final exam review, and deviates from the Econ curve to create a more equitable scale. It's heartbreaking to walk out of a class feeling like you learned a lot about the material, but not have the opportunity to demonstrate improvement.

Marina's a great teacher, great lecture slides, good and useful content 
weakness: grade heavily dependent on midterm and final
Very well taught and well organized. Problem set grading was a mess and inconsistent.

This is a well taught course. I do think that more psets would have been better. The practice psets were good, but it would have helped to have more required practice and feedback. That said, all of the problems were reasonable and well thought out. Professor Halac was very good at explaining things, and clearly cares a lot about student learning.
The only weakness is the relative lack of practical applications. Although some were mentioned in class, a few case studies wouldnt hurt.

I think that the exam questions were fair game compared to the problem sets and material from the class.

The problem sets (we only had 4 of them) took probably 4 hours and were pretty good for testing yourself.  The midterm/final weren't too difficult.  If I had a criticism, it's almost that we could have done more in the class.

The optional problems and section were one of the greatest strengths of this course. Sometimes it was hard to completely follow along during lecture but the optional problems and section really helped solidify what was taught every week.

The lectures were all very clear and taught us what we needed to know for problem sets and exams. 
The low number of problem sets sometimes made it so I neglected studying/working on game theory because of the long break until any due date.
Strengths were the teaching and material. The weakness was the number of assignments

I thought this course was extremely well taught. The lectures were very clear and helpful to follow, and the material taught in class translated well into the problem sets and exams. I felt that the problem sets did a good job of summarizing the core concepts to takeaway from lecture, and were a fair workload balance. Further, the optional problems that Professor Halac provided helped fill in any gaps that I may have had and provided useful extra practice.
More TA office hours, and the TAs did not actively help with problem sets

I thought that the class was very engaging, from in-class games to interesting historical applications of certain concepts. I also thought that the workload and test difficulty was very reasonable, and the class was focused on facilitating learning instead of obtaining certain grades.

The strengths was how engaged and passionate Professor Halac was about the subject, which showed through her well curated lectures and the interesting course material. The only weakness of the course is probably that there is immense pressure to do well on the one midterm and final, which account for almost all of your grade. If there were two midterms, or more psets throughout the semester, this stress could be alleviated.

It is strong in that the course material is interesting and Professor Halac made lectures very engaging and relatively hands-on.

The strengths outweighed the weaknesses, but I will go into detail on weaknesses. Its weaknesses are in the fact that the course material can sometimes be a little slow despite being interesting in theory. But far more importantly, there was essentially zero feedback on student performance throughout the semester. There were only four problem sets the entire semester, and they were essentially not graded (only on a check minus, check, check plus scale) and even the posted solutions were cursory and did not have sufficiently detailed ways to solve the problems. The single midterm exam was very late in the semester and was not graded until after the midterm drop deadline, so there were quite literally no grades in Canvas before the drop deadline. The exam turned out to be (empirically) skewed upwards as the mode was a 100%, and it was very unclear how the professor would choose to curve grades. The final exam was similar except for the fact that it had one question that was harder than the others, and I expect that it made the exam bimodal (though this is an assumption because final exam grades were not even posted before official final grades were posted). This was the main problem with the class  it was essentially impossible for a student to know how they were doing or how prepared they were for exams or the course as a whole.

-More detailed notes.

-More step by step solutions of key concepts. I had many questions and was very uncertain about many of the aspects of some of the exercises. Especially for the signaling games, were many things were left to be figured out entirely by the students.

The course is very structured in clear. I loved how the topics built on previous lessons. My only issue with the course is the grading breakdown. We only had six assignments over the course of the semester (four problem sets, a midterm exam, and a final exam), and so our final grade was determined by a small amount of work. Additionally, the way that the assignments were graded left little room for mistakes. The graders do not seem to understand the concept of partial credit at all, grading answers that were slightly wrong the same way they would grade blank ones. It is not fair to treat those who attempted a response and maybe missed some part of it the same way you would treat someone who didn't even attempt the question. Thus, I do not feel like my final grade will truly represent all that I learned in the course. I wish we had more assignments out of more points so that we could constantly be tested and held accountable for the material throughout the semester. That way, if you don't understand a topic, you can learn from your mistakes instead of being discouraged and punished.
Wish we had more office hours and tutoring hours. It would be nice to have peer tutors for the class.

The professor was very good, and I learned a lot that I hadn't known before. 
However, I don't really see how I can apply this knowledge to the real world. Also, we didn't learn much about the theory behind the games, we just learned how to solve them. So, even after having taken the course, I can't say I understand the material at a deep level, I just know how to solve the games.

Weakness: There should be more practice material posted for the midterm and final. Also, the midterm should be given earlier so that students have ample time to decide whether they want to drop the course or not before the deadline. By the deadline, there was only one grade, which was a homework assignment graded on a check minus, check, check plus scale. The optional problems were very difficult and were not representative of the overall difficulty of the midterm/final.

Yes, I think that this was a very interesting course that allowed you to use logic in order to solve problems with applications of which could be applied to real-world scenarios. It was a low workload with only four problem sets, optional problems each week, and optional sections. You only had to study for the midterm and the final exams which were each three questions related to the lecture and problem set material. I think that the concepts and examples of games during class would influence one's thinking and rationality in decision-making going forward in life.

This class is very chill, especially compared to the more intense game theory class.  I had a good time it and as a non-econ major found it quite relevant to the kind of thinking that will help me regardless of my career path.  It's a good SO and the math isn't very difficult.

I would recommend this course to any economics major. It serves as an introduction to an important branch in the field. It also has many applications to places beyond just economics, such as psychology, industrial organization, and global affairs.

Yes, I absolutely would recommend this class to another student. I think that this class is accessible to students from a wide range of backgrounds - economics, mathematics, those interested in logic, cognitive science, etc. I also think that the course is taught very well, and the subject matter is very interesting and useful outside of the classroom.

Yes I would if you are looking for an interesting econ elective that has applications to almost all areas of academia, including politics and international affairs. It is not too much of a weekly workload, and it is worth it just to get to know Professor Halac.
